what: Step 1 - Start with one or more data files
title: dataspice Overview
text: start user one datafiles common directory. currently support rectangular data headers .csv file spatial data attributes.

title: dataspice Overview
text: create_spice() reads files directory creates set template metadata files user populate. metadata templates include data extracted user’s datafiles, including things like file names measured variable names aid user populating metadata files. created, need fill template file remaining metadata. Templates can filled either: integrated Shiny applications (edit_attributes(), edit_access(), edit_creators(), edit_biblio()) Manually (.e., text CSV/spreadsheet editor) new even advanced users, option (1) probably easier friendly.

title: dataspice Overview
text: creators.csv: One row creator, gives affiliation, contact email, ORCID, etc. attributes.csv: user data entry take place. variable, name, units, written description filled . biblio.csv: Citation information project, much little data possible can included, things like bounding box coordinates included, website generated bounding box map generated. access.csv: Includes row file read , documents name file format.

title: dataspice Overview
text: metadata templates filled , can create single JSON-LD metadata record metadata write_spice().

title: dataspice Overview
text: dataset README website interactive representation JSON information data. Assuming sufficient information provided JSON include map points bounding box area study. output write_spice() fed build_site() create website.

what: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: goal dataspice make easier researchers create basic, lightweight, concise metadata files datasets editing kind files ’re probably familiar : CSVs. spice data dash metadata. metadata files can used : Make useful information available analysis. Create helpful dataset README webpage data similar pkgdown creates websites R packages. Produce complex metadata formats richer description datasets aid dataset discovery. Metadata fields based Schema.org/Dataset metadata standards represent lowest common denominator means converting formats relatively straightforward.

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: basic example repository demonstrating using dataspice might look like can found https://github.com/amoeba/dataspice-example. , can also check preview HTML dataspice generates https://amoeba.github.io/dataspice-example Google sees https://search.google.com/test/rich-results?url=https%3A%2F%2Famoeba.github.io%2Fdataspice-example%2F. much detailed example created Anna Krystalli https://annakrystalli./dataspice-tutorial/ (GitHub repo).

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: can install latest version CRAN:

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: diagram showing workflow using dataspice
code: create_spice() # Then fill in template CSV files, more on this below write_spice() build_site() # Optional

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: create_spice() creates template metadata spreadsheets folder (default created data folder current working directory). template files : biblio.csv - title, abstract, spatial temporal coverage, etc. creators.csv - data authors attributes.csv - explains variables dataset access.csv - files, file types, download URLs (appropriate)

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: user needs fill details four template files. csv files can directly modified, can edited using either associated helper function /Shiny app.

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: prep_attributes() populates fileName variableName columns attributes.csv file using header row data files. prep_access() populates fileName, name encodingFormat columns access.csv file files folder containing data. see example prep_attributes() works, load data files ship package: function assumes metadata templates folder called metadata within data folder. Using purrr::map(), function can applied multiple files populate header names output prep_attributes() first two columns filled :
code: data_files <- list.files(system.file("example-dataset/", package = "dataspice"),   pattern = ".csv",   full.names = TRUE ) attributes_path <- file.path("data", "metadata", "attributes.csv") data_files %>%   purrr::map(~ prep_attributes(.x, attributes_path),     attributes_path = attributes_path   )

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: metadata templates can edited interactively using Shiny app: edit_attributes() opens Shiny app can used edit attributes.csv. Shiny app displays current attributes table lets user fill informative description units (e.g. meters, hectares, etc.) variable. edit_access() opens editable version access.csv edit_creators() opens editable version creators.csv edit_biblio() opens editable version biblio.csv edit_attributes Shiny app Remember click Save finished editing.

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: first rows completed metadata tables example look like : access.csv one row file attributes.csv one row variable file biblio.csv one row containing descriptors including spatial temporal coverage creators.csv one row dataset authors

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: write_spice() generates json-ld file (“linked data”) aid dataset discovery, creation extensive metadata (e.g. EML), creating website. ’s view dataspice.json file example data: listviewer pack output showing example dataspice JSON file

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: build_site() creates bare-bones index.html file repository docs folder simple view dataset metadata interactive map. example, repository results website dataspice-website

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: metadata fields dataspice uses based largely compatibility terms Schema.org. However, dataspice metadata can converted Ecological Metadata Language (EML), much richer schema. conversion isn’t perfect dataspice best convert dataspice metadata EML: may receive warnings depending dataspice fields filled process likely produce invalid EML record totally fine: fields dataspice store information different structures EML requires many fields dataspice doesn’t fields . point, look validation errors produced EML::eml_validate fix . Note likely require familiarity EML Schema EML package. ’re done, can write EML XML file:
code: library(dataspice)  # Load an example dataspice JSON that comes installed with the package spice <- system.file(   "examples", "annual-escapement.json",   package = "dataspice" )  # Convert it to EML eml_doc <- spice_to_eml(spice) #> Warning: variableMeasured not crosswalked to EML because we don't have enough #> information. Use `crosswalk_variables` to create the start of an EML attributes #> table. See ?crosswalk_variables for help. #> You might want to run EML::eml_validate on the result at this point and fix what validations errors are produced. You will commonly need to set `packageId`, `system`, and provide `attributeList` elements for each `dataTable`. library(EML) #>  #> Attaching package: 'EML' #> The following object is masked from 'package:magrittr': #>  #>     set_attributes  eml_validate(eml_doc) #> [1] FALSE #> attr(,"errors") #> [1] "Element '{https://eml.ecoinformatics.org/eml-2.2.0}eml': The attribute 'packageId' is required but missing."                                   #> [2] "Element '{https://eml.ecoinformatics.org/eml-2.2.0}eml': The attribute 'system' is required but missing."                                      #> [3] "Element 'dataTable': Missing child element(s). Expected is one of ( physical, coverage, methods, additionalInfo, annotation, attributeList )." #> [4] "Element 'dataTable': Missing child element(s). Expected is one of ( physical, coverage, methods, additionalInfo, annotation, attributeList )." #> [5] "Element 'dataTable': Missing child element(s). Expected is one of ( physical, coverage, methods, additionalInfo, annotation, attributeList )." out_path <- tempfile() write_eml(eml_doc, out_path) #> NULL

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: Like converting dataspice EML, can convert existing EML record set dataspice metadata tables can work within dataspice:
code: library(EML)  eml_path <- system.file("example-dataset/broodTable_metadata.xml", package = "dataspice") eml <- read_eml(eml_path) # Creates four CSVs files in the `data/metadata` directory my_spice <- eml_to_spice(eml, "data/metadata")

title: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data
text: existing tools & data standards help users specific domains: Darwin Core Ecological Metadata Language (EML) (& EML) ISO 19115 - Geographic Information Metadata ISO 19139 - Geographic Info Metadata XML schema Minimum Information Biological Biomedical Investigations (MIBBI) …others indexed Fairsharing.org & RDA metadata directory.

text: Nothing. Creates/overwrites docs/index.html

title: Crosswalk dataspice variables to EML — crosswalk_variables
code: if (FALSE) { # Load an example dataspice JSON that comes installed with the package spice <- system.file(   "examples", "annual-escapement.json",   package = "dataspice")  # Convert it to EML (notice the warning) eml_doc <- suppressWarnings({spice_to_eml(spice)}) attributes <- crosswalk_variables(spice)  # Now fill in the attributes data.frame. See `EML::set_attributes`.  # And last, set the attributes on our EML document eml_doc$dataset$dataTable[[1]]$attributeList <-   EML::set_attributes(attributes) }

what: dataspice: Create Lightweight Schema.org Descriptions of Data — dataspice-package

Metadata fields based   'Schema.org' 'Ecological Metadata Language' standards.

title: Prepare access — prep_access
text: Extract fileNames data file(s) add access.csv. helper validate_file_paths can used create vectors valid file paths can checked passed data_path argument prep_access.

title: Prepare access — prep_access
text: data_path character vector either: path(s) data file(s). single path directory containing data file(s). Currently tabular .csv .tsv .rds files supported. access_path path access.csv file. Defaults data/metadata/access.csv. ... parameters passed list.files(). example, use recursive = TRUE list files folder recursively use pattern filter files patterns.

text: Updates access.csv writes access_path.

title: Prepare attributes — prep_attributes
text: Extract variableNames data file(s) add attributes.csv. helper validate_file_paths can used create vectors valid file paths can checked passed data_path argument prep_attributes.

title: Prepare attributes — prep_attributes
text: data_path character vector either: path(s) data file(s). single path directory containing data file(s). Currently tabular .csv .tsv files supported. Alternatively attributes returned using names() can extracted r object, stored .rds files. attributes_path path attributes.csv`` file. Defaults data/metadata/attributes.csv`. ... parameters passed list.files(). example, use recursive = TRUE list files folder recursively use pattern filter files patterns.

title: Prepare attributes — prep_attributes
text: prep_attributes() updates attributes.csv writes attributes_path.

title: Prepare attributes — prep_attributes
code: if (FALSE) { create_spice() # extract attributes from all `csv`, `tsv`, `rds` files in the data folder # (non recursive) prep_attributes() # recursive prep_attributes(recursive = TRUE) # extract attributes from a single file using file path data_path <- system.file("example-dataset","BroodTables.csv",                          package = "dataspice") prep_attributes(data_path) # extract attributes from a single file by file path pattern matching data_path <- system.file("example-dataset", package = "dataspice") prep_attributes(data_path, pattern = "StockInfo") # extract from a folder using folder path data_path <- system.file("example-dataset", package = "dataspice") prep_attributes(data_path) }

what: Convert dataspice metadata to EML — spice_to_eml
title: Convert dataspice metadata to EML — spice_to_eml
text: Performs (imperfect) conversion dataspice metadata EML. likely get validation errors need fix afterwards spice_to_eml good way richer metadata schema (EML) already using dataspice need richer metadata schema.

title: Convert dataspice metadata to EML — spice_to_eml
Convert dataspice metadata to EML — spice_to_eml
text: spice (list) dataspice metadata. Uses data/metadata/dataspice.json default.

title: Convert dataspice metadata to EML — spice_to_eml
text: (emld) crosswalked emld object

title: Convert dataspice metadata to EML — spice_to_eml
code: # Load an example dataspice JSON that comes installed with the package spice <- system.file(   "examples", "annual-escapement.json",   package = "dataspice" )  # And crosswalk it to EML spice_to_eml(spice) #> Warning: variableMeasured not crosswalked to EML because we don't have enough information. Use `crosswalk_variables` to create the start of an EML attributes table. See ?crosswalk_variables for help. #> You might want to run EML::eml_validate on the result at this point and fix what validations errors are produced. You will commonly need to set `packageId`, `system`, and provide `attributeList` elements for each `dataTable`. #> dataset: #>   title: Compiled annual statewide Alaskan salmon escapement counts, 1921-2017 #>   creator: #>   - individualName: #>       givenName: Jeanette #>       surName: Clark #>     organizationName: #>     - Organization #>     electronicMailAddress: jclark@nceas.ucsb.edu #>     userId: ~ #>   - individualName: #>       givenName: Rich #>       surName: Brenner #>     organizationName: #>     - Organization #>     electronicMailAddress: richard.brenner.alaska.gov #>     userId: ~ #>   abstract: The number of mature salmon migrating from the marine environment to freshwater #>     streams is defined as escapement. Escapement data are the enumeration of these #>     migrating fish as they pass upstream, and are a widely used index of spawning #>     salmon abundance. These data are important for fisheries management, since most #>     salmon harvest occurs near the mouths of rivers where salmon spawn during this #>     migration. Escapement data are collected in a variety of ways. Stationary projects #>     utilize observers stationed along freshwater corridors who count salmon as they #>     pass upriver through weirs or past elevated towers. Sonar equipment placed in #>     the river can also give a stationary escapement count. These counts usually represent #>     a sample, and are expanded to represent a 24h period. Escapement data can also #>     be collected using aerial surveys, where observers in an aircraft provide an index #>     to estimate escapement. In general, escapement counts do not represent total abundance, #>     but instead an index of abundance. Surveys are usually timed to coincide with #>     peak spawning activity, generally in the summer, but in the case of Coho salmon #>     in the fall as well. Some data about non-salmon species are also included. This #>     dataset contains compiled annual data from multiple sources. The .Rmd merges all #>     datasets, identifies and flags duplicate records, and performs quality assurance #>     checks by filtering and graphing results. #>   pubDate: ~ #>   coverage: #>     temporalCoverage: #>       rangeOfDates: #>         beginDate: #>           calendarDate: '1921-01-01' #>           time: '08:00:00' #>         endDate: #>           calendarDate: '1921-01-01' #>           time: '08:00:00' #>     geographicCoverage: #>       geographicDescription: Placeholder #>       boundingCoordinates: #>         westBoundingCoordinate: '-171' #>         eastBoundingCoordinate: '-131' #>         northBoundingCoordinate: '78' #>         southBoundingCoordinate: '47' #>   contact: #>   - individualName: #>       givenName: Jeanette #>       surName: Clark #>     organizationName: #>     - Organization #>     electronicMailAddress: jclark@nceas.ucsb.edu #>     userId: ~ #>   - individualName: #>       givenName: Rich #>       surName: Brenner #>     organizationName: #>     - Organization #>     electronicMailAddress: richard.brenner.alaska.gov #>     userId: ~ #>   dataTable: #>   - entityName: StockInfo.csv #>     physical: #>       objectName: StockInfo.csv #>       dataFormat: #>         externallyDefinedFormat: #>           formatName: CSV #>       distribution: #>         online: #>           url: http://example.com #>   - entityName: BroodTables.csv #>     physical: #>       objectName: BroodTables.csv #>       dataFormat: #>         externallyDefinedFormat: #>           formatName: CSV #>       distribution: #>         online: #>           url: http://example.com #>   - entityName: SourceInfo.csv #>     physical: #>       objectName: SourceInfo.csv #>       dataFormat: #>         externallyDefinedFormat: #>           formatName: CSV #>       distribution: #>         online: #>           url: http://example.com  # We can also create dataspice metadata from scratch and crosswalk it to EML myspice <- list(   name = "My example spice",   creator = "Me",   contact = "Me" ) spice_to_eml(myspice) #> Warning: Failed to crosswalk creator Me because it needs a type. #> Warning: Failed to crosswalk creator Me because it needs a type. #> dataset: #>   title: My example spice #>   creator: #>   - [] #>   abstract: ~ #>   pubDate: ~ #>   coverage: #>     temporalCoverage: [] #>     geographicCoverage: [] #>   contact: #>   - [] #>   dataTable: []

See prettify auto_unbox automatically unbox atomic vectors length 1. usually safer avoid instead use unbox function unbox individual elements. exception objects class AsIs (.e. wrapped ()) automatically unboxed. way mark single values length-1 arrays. ... additional conversion arguments, see also toJSON fromJSON
